Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Feldman’s voice rose, sharp and suspicious. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? I’ve been with your company for years, and now you want my credit card again?” My script fluttered uselessly in my hand. As a telemarketer, I was supposed to stay calm, answer every question, and keep him on the line. My supervisor’s words echoed: “Don’t let them hang up. Address every concern.” But my eyes kept darting to the clock. In fifteen minutes, I was supposed to be at the synagogue, leading the weekly adult Torah class. People would be gathering, expecting me to guide them through the text, to answer their questions with patience and wisdom. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—one demanding I soothe and persuade, the other that I teach and inspire. My heart pounded as Mr. Feldman’s voice grew louder, and I wondered how I could possibly be both the calm, persistent telemarketer and the thoughtful, present rabbi at the same time.
